content: Hong Kong shares rally on results, U.S. gains (9:48 PM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Hong Kong stocks jumped early Thursday after solid overnight gains on Wall Street and as China Unicom Hong Kong Ltd. and BOC Hong Kong Holdings Ltd. soared to lead a host of companies higher after reporting half-yearly results. The Hang Seng Index(HK:HSI)rose 1.4% to 19,746.48 and the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index added 1.7% to 10,427.16. Telecommunications major Unicom's shares(HK:762) CHU, +2.31% soared 9.9% and BOC Hong Kong(HK:2388) BHKLY, -2.01% added 5% after their half-year performance beat expectations. Also riding higher after reporting results, Bank of China Ltd.(HK:3988) BACHY, +1.30% Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. SUHJY, -0.37% (HK:3988)and energy major Cnooc Ltd.(HK:883) CEO, +0.49% gained 1.7%, 1.3% and 2.3%, respectively. But China Life Insurance Co. LFC, +0.50% (HK:2628)fell 1.2% on top of the 11.5% plunge in the previous session after disappointing with a fall in its half-yearly profits. China's Shanghai Composite(CN:SHCOMP)gains 0.4% to 2,550.52. Guess net profit falls, shares drop on outlook (4:40 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Apparel retailer Guess Inc. GES, -0.81% hit by a $19.5 million settlement charge, reported late Wednesday its fiscal second-quarter 2012 net profit fell to $60.7 million, or 65 cents a share, from $66.8 million, or 72 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter ended July 30 rose 17% to $677.2 million from $577.1 million. Excluding one-time items, Guess earned 84 cents a share, up from 72 cents a share a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research, who typically exclude one-time items, had predicted the company would earn 81 cents a share on $656.4 million in revenue. The company said it sees third-quarter earnings of 71 cents to 74 cents a share, less than the 84 cents a share analysts were looking for. Guess shares fell 4% to $31.80 in after-hours trade. McGraw-Hill shares rise 6.6% on break-up talk (10:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- McGraw-Hill Cos. MHP, +0.00% shares jumped 6.6% on Wednesday after a Bloomberg report on the company said it could be worth 40% more if broken up. The report cited research by J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. that concluded the conglomerate, which owns Standard & Poor's as well as well as J.D. Power & Associates, could fetch $5 billion more for shareholders by valuing its businesses separately. The company's S&P unit named a new president this week after a controversial move by the debt research firm to cut its rating on the U.S. Even with Wednesday's rise, however, McGraw-Hill shares are still down 7% in the past month. American Eagle earnings fall short of consensus (8:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- American Eagle Outfitters Inc. AEO, +1.37% said Wednesday that its fiscal second-quarter profit roughly doubled to $19.7 million, or 10 cents a share, from $9.7 million, or 5 cents a share, in the year-earlier period, when it booked a $16.2 million loss from discontinued operations. Earnings from continuing operations fell to 10 cents a share from 13 cents, while sales rose 3.7% to $675.7 million and same-store sales were flat. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had been expecting earnings of 11 cents a share on sales of $652 million. Earnings for the third quarter are expected to be in the range of 22 cents to 27 cents a share, compared to the consensus forecast of 26 cents. "Although the company has tempered sales expectations for the second half, particularly during non-peak shopping periods, sales are planned to strengthen from the first half of the year, driven by investments in key items," the group said. Inergy files $300 million IPO for pipeline unit (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Inergy L.P. nrgy, +0.00% on Wednesday filed a $300 million initial public offering for Inergy Midstream L.P., a master limited partnership to own and operate its northeast U.S. energy pipeline and storage business. Inergy Midstream L.P. will offer common units on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol NRGM. Morgan Stanley MS, +1.98% and Barclays Capital are underwriting the IPO. Kansas City, Mo.-based Inergy had disclosed plans to restructure its business units through the IPO on Aug. 9. Toll Brothers 3rd-quarter net up 54% (6:00 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Toll Brothers Inc., TOL, +1.36% the Horsham, Pa., luxury-home builder, reported fiscal third-quarter net income rose 54% on 13% lower revenue. For the quarter ended July 31, profit reached $42.1 million, or 25 cents a share, from $27.3 million, or 16 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue fell to $394.3 million from $454.2 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 4 cents a share of profit on $409.2 million of revenue. The results reflected tax benefits of $38.2 million in the latest quarter and $26.5 million a year earlier. "Our sales are gaining some traction, but consumer confidence is still weak and the housing sector remains in a fragile state," Executive Chairman Robert I. Toll said in a Wednesday statement. WPP profit rises 53% (2:51 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. advertising group WPP PLC(UK:WPP) WPPGY said Wednesday that its first-half net profit rose 53% to 230.7 million pounds ($380.7 million) from 150.8 million pounds as revenue grew 6.1% to 4,71 billion pounds. WPP said it saw the strongest growth in Asia Pacific, Latin America and other emerging markets. Comparable sales rose 5.4% in the U.S. and 5.1% in the U.K., while the rest of Western Europe lagged behind with growth of 2.9%. The group also lifted its dividend payout by 25% to 7.46 pence a share. "Given recent events, our operating companies will be even more cautious about hiring additional staff in the balance of this year," the group said. Accor swings to profit on 4.4% higher revenue (2:33 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Accor SA, ACRFF, -0.98% ACRFY (FR:AC)the Paris hotel operator, swung to a first-half profit from a year-earlier loss on 4.4% higher revenue. Net income was 41 million euros ($59.1 million) compared with a loss of 15 million in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached 2.97 billion euros from 2.85 billion. Revenue rose 5.8% on a comparable basis. Earnings before interest and taxes rose 28% to 199 million euros. "Occupancy rates rose steadily while the improvement in average room rates gradually spread across all segments," the company said in a Wednesday statement. The company pared its net debt to 559 million euros at June 30 from 730 million euros at Dec. 31. In 2011, Accor expects to open 30,000 rooms; it opened 13,700 of them in the first half. BHP Billiton fiscal-year profit surges (2:20 AM ET) SYDNEY (MarketWatch) -- Anglo-Australian mining giant BHP Billiton Ltd.(AU:BHP) BHP, +2.16% (UK:BLT)said Wednesday that its fiscal-year attributable net profit jumped 85.9% to $23.65 billion. Revenue rose 35.9% to $71.7 billion following record production across four commodities and ten operations. The firm said that robust demand, industry-wide cost pressures and persistent supply-side constraints continued to support the fundamentals for most of its core commodities. Still, tight labor and raw material markets are presenting a challenge for all operators it noted, while the devaluation of the U.S. dollar and inflation curbed profits in the year. "We expect robust demand in the short and medium term, supported by commodities intensive emerging economic growth," the company added. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Accor SA, ACRFF, -0.98% acrfy AC, -0.39% the Paris hotel operator, swung to a first-half profit from a year-earlier loss on 4.4% higher revenue. Net income was 41 million euros ($59.1 million) compared with a loss of 15 million in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached 2.97 billion euros from 2.85 billion. Revenue rose 5.8% on a comparable basis. Earnings before interest and taxes rose 28% to 199 million euros. "Occupancy rates rose steadily while the improvement in average room rates gradually spread across all segments," the company said in a Wednesday statement. The company pared its net debt to 559 million euros at June 30 from 730 million euros at Dec. 31. In 2011, Accor expects to open 30,000 rooms; it opened 13,700 of them in the first half.
title: Accor swings to profit on 4.4% higher revenue

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Shares of the following companies were among those that made notable moves in the U.S. stock market Wednesday. Advancers Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% may face the end of its 767 program if the U.S. Government Accountability Office rules this week that the Air Force was not out of line when awarding rival Northrop Grumman a $35 billion contract to build tanker aircraft. See related story. CKE Restaurants Inc.: CKR A holder of 3.6% called on the Carpinteria, Calif., operator of Carl's Jr. and Hardee's outlets to cut operating costs and reduce the capital-spending plan to improve free cash flow. Ramius LLC, a New York investment firm, made the call in a letter it made public on Wednesday. In its response, CKE said its annual meeting is set for June 19, its quarterly report is to be released June 25, and its conference call on the earnings report is June 26. Once the company makes certain disclosures tied to these events, CKE said, "we would welcome a more thorough dialogue." Read the article. CKE Restaurants Inc. CKR operator of the Carl's Jr. and Hardee's fast food chains, said Wednesday it signed an agreement to open a minimum of 100 Carl's Jr. restaurants in China over the next eight years. The company expects to open the first stores in Beijing and Shanghai respectively before March 2009. Delta Airlines DAL, +1.63% plans to reduce domestic capacity by 13% in the second half, more than the 10% it had previously announced, the airline said Wednesday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. "Delta will continue to monitor the economic and fuel environment and make additional adjustments as necessary," said the carrier. However, Delta still expects a profitable second quarter, excluding items, and its outlook on quarterly performance remains in line with previous guidance. At the same time, its liquidity remains strong due to solid operating cash flow and it sees unrestricted liquidity totaling $3.2 billion at the end of the year, down $600 million from end of 2007. DreamWorks SKG: DWA Steven Spielberg and other principals behind the company are nearing an agreement to form a new movie venture with India's Reliance ADA Group, The Wall Street Journal reported. Under the arrangement Spielberg and other DreamWorks founders will receive up to $600 million in equity to launch the new venture, in which Reliance will have a large stake, The new venture is likely to seek out an additional $500 million in debt financing to fund the development of about six films a year, the Journal reported. Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54% shares climbed nearly 5% at one point Wednesday, gaining as the drugmaker reached an agreement that would allow India's Ranbaxy Laboratories Ltd. to market a generic version of Pfizer's blockbuster Lipitor in 2011. See related story. Sanofi-Aventis SFY, -0.17% said Wednesday that it intends to offer $2.56 billion for Czech generic drugmaker Zentiva, topping an earlier offer from financial group PPF. The bid pits Zentiva's two biggest shareholders against each other and is a further sign that major branded-drug companies are keen to build their presence in the generics business. See related story. Decliners Ambak Financial Group Inc. ABK, +0.00% said Wednesday it terminated its ratings contract with Fitch Ratings Inc. "Our decision to refocus and realign our business around our core expertise in the public finance and infrastructure sectors has led us to re-evaluate our ratings needs," Ambac said in a statement. "As part of this review, we have asked Fitch to remove its ratings on Ambac and all its subsidiaries effective immediately." Fitch has maintained a AA rating on Ambac since cutting its AAA rating in mid-January. AMR Corp. AMR, -4.53% the parent company of American Airlines and American Eagle, said Wednesday it expects to take delivery of more fuel-efficient aircraft over the next few years and is considering speeding up the retirement of less fuel-efficient aircraft. AMR said it still expects to take delivery of 70 Boeing 737-800 aircraft in 2009 and 2010 as a replacement to its MD-80 fleet. CarMax Inc. KMX, +2.14% first-quarter earnings fell to $29.6 million, or 13 cents a share, from $65.4 million, or 30 cents, in the year-ago period. Sales increased 3% to $2.21 billion from $2.15 billion. This increase was led by a 6% increase in used-vehicle revenue. "The slowdown in the economy, the dramatic rise in gasoline and food costs and the related impact on consumer spending adversely affected our first quarter performance," said Tom Folliard, president and chief executive officer. "Results for the full year could be significantly below the bottom of our original earnings guidance range." The company suspended its fiscal 2009 earnings estimates. Chicken Producers: The companies and investors had hoped seasonal demand for poultry in the summer and reduced output would offer the industry some relief from rising feed-grain prices. Now, with some corn and soybean crops expected to be lost to flooding in nation's grain-belt coupled with an unexpected price decline in boneless chicken breast meat, shares of chicken producers - Pilgrim's Pride, PPC, -1.16% Sanderson SAFM, -3.36% and Tyson TSN, +0.36% -- have been hurt. Read the article. Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% said Wednesday it will exit 15 cities and retire all its 737-300s by 2009, as it seeks to get out of less profitable cities and rids itself of inefficient aircraft amid turmoil in the industry. The airline said it also needs to eliminate 3000 positions. Speaking at the Merrill Lynch Global Transportation Conference, Continental's chairman and CEO Lawrence Kellner said his priorities is to get the company back on a stable keel in a time of extreme volatility. Dana Holding Corp. DAN, +3.08% agreed to settle environmental liabilities at six toxic-waste sites for $125.7 million, the Department of Justice said. The Environmental Protection Agency, the Commerce Department, and the Interior Department had brought charges against Dana -- which recently emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection -- and 40 affiliated companies. FedEx Corp. FDX, +2.26% swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $241 million, or 78 cents a share, from profit of $610 million, or $1.96 a share, a year earlier. The latest results were hurt by a charge of $2.22 a share related to the Kinko's acquisition. The Memphis shipping company said that excluding items, earnings were $1.45 against $1.90. Revenue for the quarter ended May 31 increased 8% to $9.87 billion from $9.15 billion. See full story. Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% shares fell significantly Wednesday, retreating in the wake of the company announcing a reduction in its dividend and plans to raise $2 billion in new capital from convertible preferred shares and the sale of non-core assets. See related story. Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% shares dropped 7% to $6.14 Wednesday, leading a broad decline in the auto sector a day after the company's top brass reportedly sat down for a meeting with prominent shareholder Kirk Kerkorian to discuss restructuring plans. Ford also said Tuesday that it would extend planned summer shutdowns at factories that build super-duty pickups and full-size sports utility vehicles. Gannett Co.'s GCI, +0.50% total advertising revenue fell 14.3% to $347.1 million in May from $404.9 million in May 2007. Total revenue declined 10.9% to $536.1 million from $601.4 million a year earlier. The biggest percentage slide last month was in classified ad revenue, which dropped 18.8% to $135.1 million from $166.1 million a year ago. H&R Block Inc. HRB, +1.03% said its board amended the bylaws to provide for a non-binding vote of holders on the pay and performance policies. The tax service company also decided not to renew the poison-pill clause. It expired in March. At the same time, the board limit was reduced to 12 members from the previous 15. Meanwhile, H&R Block plans to seek shareholder approval at the annual meeting to include the provisions separating the chairman and chief executive positions in the company's articles of incorporation. Lehman Brothers Holdings LEH is not in discussions for a sale of the company and Chief Executive Richard Fuld is not considering a sale, Reuters Thomson reported Wednesday, citing a person close to the firm. Speculation that Lehman may be putting itself on the block has swirled amid dismal second-quarter earnings. On Monday, Lehman reported a loss of $2.8 billion, its first quarterly loss since the company went public in 1994. Lubrizol Corp. LZ plans to curtail acrylic-emulsion operations at its plant in Avon Lake, Ohio, and move production to other sites as a part of its effort to realign its U.S. manufacturing facilities amid increases in energy costs. The company will also stop production of styrene butadiene latex at its Gastonia, N.C. plant. As a result of these actions, Lubrizol is expected to incur additional restructuring and impairment in the first quarter. MF Global Ltd. MF, +0.88% estimated that narrower short-term credit spreads hurt fiscal first-quarter net interest income and pretax profit margins. The company estimated the quarter's revenue at $360 million to $390 million. It expects to report $6 million to $8 million of costs for staff cuts. And it plans to raise about $300 million through private offerings of $150 million of non-cumulative perpetual convertible preference shares and $150 million of convertible senior notes. Microsoft Corp., MSFT, +2.10% the Redmond, Wash., software firm, said it acquired closely held Navic Networks, the Waltham, Mass., provider of tools that use real-time audience-measurement data to ensure efficient delivery and placement of interactive ads. Terms weren't disclosed. Navic's technology helps deliver advertising and interactive-TV applications via more than 35 million digital set-top boxes in North America, Microsoft said in a statement on Wednesday. Morgan Stanley MS, +1.98% reported second-quarter profit fell 60% to $1.03 billion, or 95 cents a share, from $2.58 billion, or $2.45, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $6.51 billion from $10.5 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected the firm to report profit of 95 cents a share on revenue of $7.05 billion. Northwest Airlines Corp. NWA said it plans to cut capacity by 8.5% to 9.5% in the fourth quarter. "In response to these extraordinary fuel costs, we are taking prudent actions to reduce our capacity and right-size the airline," Doug Steenland, Northwest's chief executive, said in a statement. "This will allow us to better match our capacity to customer demand as airfares, by necessity, must increase." See full story Philip Morris International Inc., PM, -0.39% the Lausanne, Switzerland, tobacco company, declared on Wednesday an initial quarterly dividend of 46 cents a share, payable July 10 to holders of record June 30. In May, the company began a two-year $13 billion share-buyback program. Southwest Airlines LUV, +1.83% said Wednesday it is committed to add 14 aircraft this year, but may also retire some of its older planes as it adjusts to a higher-fuel cost environment. Speaking at a New York investor conference, CEO Gary Kelly said the Dallas-based low-cost carrier should end the year with 533 to 535 planes compared to 520 planes at the end of 2007. Thornburg Mortgage Inc. TMA shares were down nearly 5% at 66 cents after the company in a filing Wednesday said the Securities and Exchange Commission has requested documents as part of an investigation related to an earnings restatement, margin calls and other matters. Thornburg said it has provided the SEC with documents responsive to the April 24 and May 23 subpoenas, and is cooperating with the regulator in its investigation. Thornburg has been roiled by the subprime mortgage crunch and housing pullback, and its shares are off nearly 80% over the past three months. Tyson Foods Inc. TSN, +0.36% and its subsidiaries were downgraded by Fitch Ratings because high grain costs are expected to cut into profit. Fitch lowered its BBB- ratings on Tyson, Tyson Fresh Meats Inc., and Lakeside Farm Industries Ltd. to BB+. Fitch said Tyson had about $3 billion in debt as of March 29. The outlook is negative. Travel - Europe: ABN Amro took a hatchet to its European travel-and-leisure-sector ratings, cutting earnings per share for 2009-2010 by 16% and bringing it 15% below consensus estimates. Carnival, CCL, +1.45% (CCL) Enterprise Inns, ETINF, -30.73% (ETI) Marstons (MARS) and Ladbrokes LDBKY (LAD) were downgraded to hold from buy, Royal Caribbean RCL, +1.04% was cut to sell from buy, and J.D. Wetherspoon JDWPY, +2.28% (JDW) and Accor ACRFF, -0.98% (012040) were cut to sell from hold. Rank Group RANKF, -0.97% (RNK) was upped to hold from sell. UBS: UBS, +0.40% The U.K. activist investor Olivant has built up its stake in to 2.5% and repeated calls for a major shakeup of the Swiss financial giant. Read the article. Yahoo Inc. YHOO has lost two more prominent executives in what some analysts see as a sign of mounting strain at the beleaguered Web portal as it reels from a proxy war over its aborted merger with Microsoft Corp. Caterina Fake and Stewart Butterfield, co-founders of Flickr, are both out the door in the span of a month. See related story. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are likely to see active trading during Wednesday's session are JPMorgan Chase & Co., Coca-Cola Co., eBay Inc., and Teradyne Inc. JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, +1.82% is forecast to report earnings of 90 cents a share for the third quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Coca-Cola Co. KO, +0.25% is expected to report earnings of 68 cents a share in the third quarter. EBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% is expect to post third-quarter net earnings of 33 cents a share. Teradyne Inc. TER, +1.96% is forecast to report third-quarter net earnings of 18 cents a share. Abbott Laboratories ABT, +1.16% is expected to post net earnings of 66 cents a share in the third quarter. Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% is forecast to post third-quarter net earnings of $1 a share. E-Trade Financial Corp. ETFC, +3.38% is expected to report net earnings of 10 cents a share in the third quarter. United Technologies Corp. UTX, +1.10% is expected to report net earnings of $1.16 a share in the third quarter. Washington Mutual Inc. WM, +1.13% is forecast to report third-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share. Logitech International SA LOGI, +0.30% is expected to report fiscal second-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share. Watch List After Tuesday's closing bell, Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% the world's No. 1 chipmaker, reported a 43% increase in third quarter profit, boosted by strong demand in the computer market. The technology giant posted earnings per share of 31 cents, up more than 40% from the same quarter last year, and higher than the consensus Wall Street estimate of 30 cents. Analysts were expecting revenue of 9.6 billion for the quarter, according to Thomson Financial. It also named Stacy Smith as the company's new CFO and announced that it plans to cut 2,000 jobs in the fourth quarter, reducing its total headcount to about 86,000. See full story. French hotels group Accor S A ACRFF, -0.98% reported third-quarter revenue of 2.1 billion euros, up 7.9% from 1.95 billion euros a year ago. It expects to report 870 million euros to 890 million euros in pre-tax income for the full year. The outlook takes into account expectations for continued strong demand in the fourth quarter, marketing expenditure related to launch of new hotel brands, and the disposals of Go Voyages, Red Roof Inn and the Italian food services business, said Accor. AMB Property Corp. AMB, +0.00% said its third-quarter net income rose to $73.1 million from $33.4 million a year ago. After the payment of preferred stock dividends, the company posted earnings per share for the quarter of 69 cents, up from 33 cents in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $166.3 million from $180.3 million a year ago. Analysts estimated earnings of 53 cents a share, funds from operations of 82 cents, and revenue of $176.9 million. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said it determined it cannot report its recently spun-off institutional pharmacy business as discontinued operations, and provided guidance accordingly. The company said it expects full-year earnings from continuing operations of $2.58 to $2.66 a share, including 8 cents a share from the institutional pharmacy business through the July 31 spin-off date. The range implies fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of 59 cents to 67 cents a share, including a 1 cent a share contribution from the institutional pharmacy business. Bank of the Ozarks Inc. OZRK, +2.01% raised its quarterly dividend to 12 cents a share. The dividend will be paid Nov. 2 to shareholders of record as of Oct. 26. Bon-Ton Stores Inc. BONT said it doesn't expect to achieve its previously stated full-year fiscal 2007 earnings guidance, based on year-to-date third-quarter results and "continued general softness in the retail environment." In August, the department store chain predicted full-year earnings of $2.75 to $2.90 a share. Analysts expect year earnings of $2.44 a share. The company plans to update guidance Nov. 29. CBS Corp. CBS, -0.94% said it extended the employment agreement for Chief Executive Les Moonves to Sept. 30, 2011. Under the agreement, Moonves gets a salary of $3.5 million a year, compared with $5.9 million in his previous contract, which included $2.9 million in deferred compensation. Moonves will be eligible for an annual performance bonus and equity-based compensation that ties the value of the agreement to the performance of CBS shares. See full story. Champion Enterprises Inc.'s CHB, +0.22% third-quarter net income rose 43% to $12.9 million, or 17 cents a share, from $9.02 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier. The prefabricated-housing company said sales increased 3% to $357.7 million from $346.5 million. Analysts expected earnings of 14 cents a share on revenue of $369 million. Revenue from its manufacturing unit rose 11% to $260.4 million from $293.4 million, while Champion's international unit jumped to $85.3 million from $30.9 million. Retail revenue fell 42% to $18.2 million from $31.4 million. Countrywide Financial Corp. CFC, +5.04% said it will incur a pre-tax restructuring charge of $125 million to $150 million stemming from lower mortgage market origination volumes. Of the total amount of the pre-tax restructuring charge, about $57 million is expected to be recognized in the quarter ending Sept. 30, with the remaining expected to be reflected primarily in the following quarter. Crown Holdings Inc. CCK, +1.20% said its third-quarter net income rose to $92 million, or 56 cents a share, compared with $85 million, or 50 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue grew to $2.15 billion from $2 billion a year ago. Analysts estimated earnings of 58 cents a share on revenue of $2.17 billion. CSX Corp. CSX, +2.58% posted a third-quarter profit of $407 million, or 91 cents a share, up from $328 million, or 71 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding 24 cents a share from discontinued operations, the most recent quarterly profit came in at 67 cents a share. Revenue for the railroad operator rose 3% to $2.5 billion, as improved revenue per unit more than made up for a decline in volume. Analysts had expected a profit of 62 cents a share on sales of $2.49 billion. Standard & Poor's upgraded its outlook on Delta Air Lines Inc.'s DAL, +1.63% credit ratings to positive from stable, citing the carrier's "strong earnings, cash flow generation, and debt reduction." S&P affirmed its B corporate-credit ratings for Delta. "High fuel prices and potentially softening demand as a result of the weak economy may make these targets challenging," S&P said in a statement. Fulton Financial Corp.'s FULT, +0.11% third-quarter net income fell 31% to $33.6 million, or 19 cents a share, from $48.3 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier on a $16 million charge related to mortgage banking operations at Resource Bank. The financial holding company's net interest income decreased 2.8% to $122.4 million from $125.9 million a year ago. Fulton increased its provision for loan losses to $4.61 million from $555,000 a year ago. Total assets reached $15.4 billion as of Sept. 30, up from $14.9 billion a year earlier, the company said. IBM Corp. IBM, +0.60% reported a third-quarter profit from continuing operations of $2.36 billion, or $1.68 a share, on $24.12 billion in revenue. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast a profit of $1.67 a share on $24.09 billion in sales. Among its main business areas, IBM said its total services revenue reached $13.67 billion and the company reported new services bookings of $11.8 billion. See full story Linear Technology Corp. LLTC said earnings for its first fiscal quarter slipped more than 4%. For the period ended Sept. 30, the semiconductor manufacturer reported earnings of $91.5 million, or 40 cents a share, compared to earnings of $112.4 million, or 37 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue fell to $281.5 million from $292.1 million last year. Analysts were expecting earnings of 38 cents a share on revenue of $282 million. Marathon Oil Corp. MRO, +5.29% said shareholders of Western Oil Sands Inc. approved the proposed purchase of the company. The deal is expected to close Thursday, it said. News Corp.'s NWS, +1.90% MySpace and eBay Inc.'s EBAY, +0.32% Skype agreed to put Internet calls into MySpace's instant-messaging feature to attract more users and boost distribution of their two services, The Wall Street Journal reported on its website Tuesday. The companies will share revenue from the partnership but other terms weren't disclosed, said the newspaper. NovaStar Financial Inc. NFI, +0.90% agreed to sell its mortgage servicing rights and advances related to Saxon Mortgage Services Inc. for about $175 million to reduce debt. The residential mortgage portfolio manager expects to significantly reduce its servicing work force of about 300 people following the transaction, which is scheduled to close Nov. 1. The deal doesn't include the NovaStar servicing platform or preclosing liabilities, the company said. Seagate Technology Inc. STX, +2.87% said its fiscal first-quarter net income rose to $355 million, or 64 cents a share, from $19 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $3.29 billion from $2.79 billion a year ago. Analysts estimated earnings of 64 cents a share on revenue of $3.22 billion. Spansion Inc.'s SPSN, +0.65% third-quarter loss widened to $71.6 million, or 53 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $22.1 million, or 17 cents a share. The flash-memory chip-maker said sales fell 9.4% to $611.1 million from $674.7 million. Analysts expected a loss of 54 cents a share on revenue of $633 million. Spansion expects fourth-quarter sales of $640 million to $700 million. Gross margin in the fourth quarter is expected to be about flat. Steel Dynamics Inc.'s STLD, +3.56% third-quarter net income fell 15% to $100.6 million, or $1.06 a share, from $118.7 million, or $1.09 a share, a year earlier. Results from the most recent period include about 1 cent a share in purchase accounting adjustments from the company's July acquisition of The Techs. The steel company's revenue rose 27% to $1.16 billion from $911.9 million in the year-ago period. Analysts expected per-share earnings of $1.06 on revenue of $1.04 billion. Steel Dynamics said it expects fourth-quarter per-share earnings of $1.02 to $1.07, excluding any impact from the planned acquisition of OmniSource Corp. Usana Health Sciences Inc.'s USNA, +0.76% third-quarter net income rose 10% to $11.3 million, or 68 cents a share, from $10.2 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier on stock repurchases and a lower than expected effective tax rate. Earnings from continuing operations rose to 70 cents a share from 56 cents. The nutritional, personal care and weight-management product provider's sales increased 15% to $106.2 million from $92 million a year ago. Analysts predicted third-quarter earnings of 66 cents a share and revenue of $106.4 million. Usana Health expects fourth-quarter earnings of 66 cents to 68 cents a share and revenue of $108 million to $110 million. Analysts predicted net income of 68 cents a share and revenue of $112 million. Yahoo Inc. YHOO said its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 5% from the period a year earlier, as the flagging Internet company undertook a broad reorganization under its new CEO. It said net income for the period ended in September fell to $151.3 million, or 11 cents a share, from $158.5 million, or 11 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. Meanwhile total revenue rose to $1.77 billion from $1.58 billion. Analysts expected Yahoo to report earnings of 8 cents a share, and net sales of $1.24 billion. title: Stocks in focus for Wednesday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- French hotels group Accor S A late Tuesday reported third-quarter revenue of 2.1 billion euros, up 7.9% from 1.95 billion euros a year ago. It expects to report 870 million euros to 890 million euros in pre-tax income for the full year. The outlook takes into account expectations for continued strong demand in the fourth quarter, marketing expenditure related to launch of new hotel brands, and the disposals of Go Voyages, Red Roof Inn and the Italian food services business, said Accor.
title: Accor Q3 rev EUR2.1 bln vs EUR1.95 bln

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- The $3.3 billion sale of the Fairmont luxury hotel-resort chain to an investment company and a Saudi Arabian prince could be announced as soon as Monday, according to a media report. Colony Capital LLC and Prince Alwaleed bin Talal are near a deal to buy Fairmont Hotels & Resorts Inc. FHR, +5.53% which has 33,000 rooms in 88 properties around the world, The Wall Street Journal reported in its online edition, citing unnamed people familiar with the matter. See Wall Street Journal story (subscription required). The deal is for $45 a share, a slight premium to the stock's Friday closing at $43.82, The Journal said. . In the past three months, Fairmont shares have climbed nearly 50% in the past three months as investors anticipated a sale, The Journal said. Such a deal could represent a major victor for investor Carl Icahn, who in 2005 acquired a nearly 10% stake in Toronto-based Fairmont and has been it to improve shareholder value, The Journal said. Fairmont's board previously rejected Icahn's offer of $40 a share to take control of the company. And such a deal would extend Colony's collection of luxury resort and real-estate assets, which include the Raffles hotel group and the Resorts International gambling concern, The Journal said. Prince Alwaleed, one of the world's richest individuals, has once had or currently maintains stakes in London's Savoy Hotel, New York's Plaza Hotel and Geneva's Hotel des Bergues, The Journal said. Colony and Prince Alwaleed are getting some of the most desirable properties in the business, including two massive properties in Bermuda, resorts across Canadian ski destinations and a Maui hotel and golf club. Since its founding in 1991, Los Angeles-based Colony has invested in assets valued at a combined $15.6 billion, The Journal said. Over the past year the company has bought four casinos from Harrah's Entertainment Inc. HET, +0.94% and Caesars Entertainment Inc. CZR, +3.21% as part of the merger of those firms; made a $1.21 billion investment in European lodging company Accor SA (012040) ACRFF, -0.98% and begun a substantial investment rollout in Japan, The Journal said. title: Fairmont hotel chain near sale: WSJ
